attributes.title: Sweet as sugar: The effect of fasting and glucose or stevia load on the acute stress response
attributes.description:
One purpose of the acute stress response is the support of an organism’s survival through mobilization of energy. Hereby, The release of adrenaline and cortisol triggers a wealth of different physiological processes that eventually lead to increased glucose availability (de Kloet, Joëls, & Holsboer, 2005). Paradoxically, a sufficient blood glucose level seems to be necessary for an HPA axis response to stress (Rohleder & Kirschbaum, 2007). n 1997, Kirschbaum and colleagues observed that fasting study participants with low euglycemic blood glucose levels showed no rise in cortisol in response to acute psychosocial stress, while study participants who had fasted but consumed a glucose-rich beverage just prior to the stressor had normal cortisol responses to stress (Kirschbaum et al., 1997). A follow-up study demonstrated that neither fat nor protein consumption prior to stress had a similar effect (Gonzalez-Bono et al., 2002), suggesting that glucose consumption prior to the stressor is key. 
With this project, we aim at disentangling the potential hedonic and metabolic effects of glucose by independently manipulating the sweetness and the energy content of a beverage that a participant consumes before being exposed to a psychosocial stressor. Furthermore, we want to explore whether the knowledge about the content of a drink is sufficient to change the physiological reaction to it.

q1.value: Sweet as sugar: The effect of fasting and glucose or stevia load on the acute stress response

q2.value: Maria Meier, Jens Pruessner, Eva Unternaehrer

q3.value:
One purpose of the acute stress response is the support of an organism’s survival through mobilization of energy. Hereby, The release of adrenaline and cortisol triggers a wealth of different physiological processes that eventually lead to increased glucose availability (de Kloet, Joëls, & Holsboer, 2005). 

Paradoxically, a sufficient blood glucose level seems to be necessary for an HPA axis response to stress (Rohleder & Kirschbaum, 2007). In 1997, Kirschbaum and colleagues observed that fasting study participants with low euglycemic blood glucose levels showed no rise in cortisol in response to acute psychosocial stress, while study participants who had fasted but consumed a glucose-rich beverage just prior to the stressor had normal cortisol responses to stress (Kirschbaum et al., 1997). A follow-up study demonstrated that neither fat nor protein consumption prior to stress had a similar effect (Gonzalez-Bono et al., 2002), suggesting that glucose consumption prior to the stressor is key.  

With this project, we aim at disentangling the potential hedonic and metabolic effects of glucose by independently manipulating participants expectations of the energy content of a beverage, and the energy content of a beverage that a participant consumes before being exposed to a psychosocial stressor. 

For this purpose we conducted the following study:
After an online screening, eligible female participants were invited to the laboratory in groups of four after an overnight-fast of at least 8h. After an introductory phase, each participant received a letter telling her whether or not the drink she is about to drink contains energy (energy prime). Within the letter, participants were also encouraged not to disclose the information in the letter to other participants, or the experimenters. Directly after reading the letter, participants drank either a beverage (200ml) containing sugar (25g), or an equally sweet beverage containing artificial-sweetener (25g of borchers bff Stevia Kristall, rebaudiosid A with erythrit) (energy load). After the completion of questionnaires, participants were exposed to the Trier Social Stress Test for Groups (TSST-G; von Dawans et al., 2011). In a recovery period following the TSST-G, participants completed questionnaires. Finally, they were debriefed and compensated for participation. Physiological (cortisol, alpha amylase, heart rate) and subjective stress measures (arousal and mood), and blood glucose levels were assessed repeatedly throughout the experiment. Furthermore, to compare the effects of stevia and glucose load on physiological responses to stress after fasting to those of water load, we will include a water control group from another experiment in our analysis. The experimental procedure (schedule of physiological markers, TSST-G, ect.) in the former experiment was the same, except that there was no energy priming, no heart rate monitoring, and only three glucose measurements (no 45min measurement).

q4.value:
H1: We hypothesize that cortisol, alpha amylase, high-frequency heart-rate variability (HF-HRV) trajectories, and subjective pleasure and arousal will differ between the groups consuming a sweet drink compared to those consuming water.

H2: We hypothesize that cortisol, alpha amylase, HF-HRV trajectories, and subjective pleasure and arousal will differ between the groups consuming a caloric drink compared to those consuming a non-caloric drink.
 
H3: We hypothesize that cortisol, alpha amylase, HF-HRV trajectories, subjective pleasure and arousal will differ between the groups depending on the energy prime.

H4: In an exploratory hypothesis, we will test the combined effects of sweetness of the drink, calorie-content and energy prime on cortisol, alpha amylase, HF-HRV trajectories, subjective pleasure and arousal in a interaction model.

Notice: We hypothesize that there are no differences in baseline physiological values (cortisol, alpha amylase, HF-HRV, blood glucose), any other descriptive variables (such as age, BMI, BDI), or testing related variables (session start) between the experimental groups. If there are differences between the groups in any of those variables, we will account for them in subsequent analyses.
We hypothesize that sugar load leads to an increase in blood glucose levels compared to water load, or stevia load respectively.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: This is an experimental study (double blind) with random allocation of participants to four conditions (between subject design with 2 factors (factor 1: energy prime, levels: high and low; factor 2: energy load, levels: high and low), and a water control group.

q9.value:
For N = 100 participants, a third person not involved in testing prepared an envelope containing a letter with the manipulation, a bag filled with either 25g of sugar, or 25g of (equally looking) artificial sweetener, and an envelope containing a debriefing for each participant. All materials were labelled with a participant identification number (PIN, numbers 1 to 100). The list containing the information about the random allocation of PINs to the four different study groups was not accessible for the individuals involved in testing the participants. 
Participants arriving at the laboratory were given the next available PIN (in an increasing order).

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Data collection has been completed in December 2019. The biochemical assays to analyse salivary measures (cortisol and alpha amylase) are run starting from January 2020. The data analysis will be conducted as soon as the cortisol and alpha amylase assays are completed.

question.value:
An online screening questionnaire on the platform Qualtrics (https://psychkonstanz.eu.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_cUUYhYjxVs05bqR) was used to check the eligibility of participants for the study. 

Screening took place for the following exclusion criteria: (1) age younger than 18, or older than 35 years, (2) current pregnancy, (3) symptoms of moderate to severe depression (indicated by a Beck’s Depression Inventory sum score < 19), (4) being under- or overweight (indicated by a body mass index < 17.5, or > 30), (5) smoking more than 3 cigarettes per day, (6) working night-shifts, (7) history of brain damage, (8) current drug or medication intake affecting the autonomous, endocrine or central nervous system, (9) being intolerant or allergic to sugar or artificial-sweeteners, (10) deliberately avoiding sugar in the diet, (11) being not female, (12) an irregular menstrual cycle, (13) inadequate knowledge of German.

Recruitment took place via flyers at the University of Constance and the Constance University of Applied Science, via study participant databases provided by the University of Konstanz (SONA). Participants received financial compensation of €25, or, for psychology students at the University of Constance, study participation credits (2.5h).

q13.value: Overall, a sample of N = 150 participants will be investigated.

q14.value: Based on restriction of resources and feasibility considerations, we decided to assessed a total of n = 100 participants, with 25 participants in each condition (Glucose+, Glucose-, Stevia+, Stevia-), prior to conducting the study. Further, another 50 participants will be used as a control group (Water). Based on this sample we achieve a 80 % power to detect effects sizes of at least f = .34 at a significance level of .05.

question.value:
Participants came to the laboratory in a fasted state to ensure blood glucose levels are within the low euglycemic range at the beginning of the experimental procedure.

Within the experiment, we conducted two manipulations:
(1) energy prime (low, "the drink contains artificial sweetener" vs. high, "the drink contains sugar"): After an introductory phase, each participant received a letter telling her whether or not the drink she is about to drink contains energy. Within the letter, participants were encouraged not to disclose the information in the letter to other participants, or the experimenters. The water control group did not receive an energy priming letter.

(2) energy load (low, artificial-sweetener consumption vs. high, sugar consumption): Directly after the energy priming, participants drank either a beverage (200ml) containing sugar (25g), or an equally sweet beverage containing artificial-sweetener (25g of borchers bff Stevia Kristall, rebaudiosid A with erythrit). The control group drank water only.

Questionnaire data: demographic data, physical and mental health, depressive symptoms (using the Beck's Depression Inventory II), chronic stress (using the Trier Inventory for Chronic Stress Screening Scale), mood (Positive and Negative Affect Scale)locus of control (using FKK), self-esteem (Rosenberg Scale of Self Esteem), stress eating (Salzburger Stress Eating Scale), food craving (Food Craving Questionnaire), early life adversities (Parental Bonding Instrument, Childhood Trauma Questionnaire), manipulation check and sweetness estimate of beverage consumed.

Repeated measures of salivary cortisol, salivary alpha amylase, blood glucose levels, heart rate and high frequency heart rate variability by means of respiratory sinus arrhythmia.

***Please note:***
The water control group was "recycled" from another study to save financial and personnel resources. This was possible since the experimental schedules were very similar. However, some questionnaire data, such as data on stress eating are not available for this group.

H1:
- Dependent variables (DVs): repeated measures of cortisol, alpha amylase, HR-HRV (respiratory sinus arrhythmia), subjective pleasure, and arousal
- Independent variable: sweetness of the drink (2 levels: sweet vs. not sweet, see above)
- Statistical Models: growth curve approach estimating within-subject trajectories of each DV over time on level 1, individual differences on level 2, and differences caused by sweetness of the drink on level 3. We plan to model a baseline model (including intercept only), a random intercept model, a random slope model, and a linear, quadratic, and cubic trend of time, and the interaction of time x sweetness. Resulting changes in overall model fit by means of the log-likelihood value will be compared using an ANOVA and the final model will be evaluated.

H2:
- Dependent variables (DVs): repeated measures of cortisol, alpha amylase, HR-HRV (respiratory sinus arrhythmia), subjective pleasure, and arousal
- Independent variable: energy load of the drink (2 levels: high vs. low, see above)
- Statistical Models: growth curve approach estimating within-subject trajectories of each DV over time on level 1, individual differences on level 2, and differences caused by energy load of the drink on level 3. We plan to model a baseline model (including intercept only), a random intercept model, a random slope model, and a linear, quadratic, and cubic trend of time, and the interaction of time x energy load. Resulting changes in overall model fit by means of the log-likelihood value will be compared using an ANOVA and the final model will be evaluated.

H3:
- Dependent variables (DVs): repeated measures of cortisol, alpha amylase, HR-HRV (respiratory sinus arrhythmia), subjective pleasure, and arousal
- Independent variable: energy prime (2 levels: high vs. low, see above)
- Statistical Models: growth curve approach estimating within-subject trajectories of each DV over time on level 1, individual differences on level 2, and differences caused by energy load of the drink on level 3. We plan to model a baseline model (including intercept only), a random intercept model, a random slope model, and a linear, quadratic, and cubic trend of time, and the interaction of time x energy prime. Resulting changes in overall model fit by means of the log-likelihood value will be compared using an ANOVA and the final model will be evaluated.

H4:
- Dependent variables (DVs): repeated measures of cortisol, alpha amylase, HR-HRV (respiratory sinus arrhythmia), subjective pleasure, and arousal
- Independent variable: sweetness of the drink (2 levels: sweet vs. not sweet), energy load of the drink (2 levels: high vs. low), energy prime (2 levels: high vs. low, see above)
- Statistical Models: growth curve approach estimating within-subject trajectories of each DV over time on level 1, individual differences on level 2, and differences caused by IVs on level 3. We plan to model a baseline model (including intercept only), a random intercept model, a random slope model, and a linear, quadratic, and cubic trend of time, and the interaction of time x IVs. Resulting changes in overall model fit by means of the log-likelihood value will be compared using an ANOVA and the final model will be evaluated.

q21.value: We use an alpha level of alpha = .05.

q22.value: We will winsorize the existing data by replacing values that exceeded the mean by more than 3SD (outliers) with 3SD.

q23.value:
Questionnaire data: If no more than 30% of the items of a (sub)scale are missing, missing items will be imputed using the mean of the items of the subscale. Else, the score will not be computed and the participant will be excluded in the according analysis.

Biological data: Missing values will be imputed either by the mean of the experimental condition if the value is missing at the first, group peak or last sample, or linearly in all remaining samples.

Gonzalez-Bono, E., Rohleder, N., Hellhammer, D. H., Salvador, A., & Kirschbaum, C. (2002). Glucose but not protein or fat load amplifies the cortisol response to psychosocial stress. Hormones and behavior, 41(3), 328-333.

Kirschbaum, C., Bono, E. G., Rohleder, N., Gessner, C., Pirke, K. M., Salvador, A., & Hellhammer, D. H. (1997). Effects of fasting and glucose load on free cortisol responses to stress and nicotine. The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism, 82(4), 1101-1105.

Rohleder, N., & Kirschbaum, C. (2007). Effects of nutrition on neuro-endocrine stress responses. Current Opinion in Clinical Nutrition & Metabolic Care, 10(4), 504-510.

attributes.title: Positive Psychology, Emotion Regulation and Sleep

q1.value: Relationships Between the Positive Psychology Dimensions, Emotion Regulation and Sleep

q2.value: Amber Tout, Eleanor Miles, Donna Jessop

q3.value:
Recent research has established links between the various dimensions of positive psychology (e.g. gratitude, optimism, mindfulness, self-compassion) and improved sleep quality and quantity (e.g. Emmons & McCullough, 2003; Lemola et al., 2011; 2013; Kemper et al., 2015; Wood et al., 2009; Black et al., 2015; Uchino et al., 2017; Howell et al., 2008; 2010; Hu et al., 2018; Butz et al., 2018). The  current study aims to replicate and extend these findings by assessing the relative importance of each dimension and its relationship to sleep, as opposed to focusing on one at a time. 
In addition, the current study will take the opportunity to explore the potential role of emotion regulation in this relationship. Previous attempts to explore the underlying mechanisms of this relationship have relied primary on single-mediator models, revealing the importance of variables such as depressive mood, rumination, perceived stress, positive and negative affect, pre-sleep cognitions, procrastination and cognitive reappraisal etc. in mediating the previously found relationships (e.g. Butz et al., 2018; Hu et al., 2018; Uchino et al. 2017; Wood et al., 2009). However, it remains unclear whether the positive-dimension - sleep relationship can be explained more broadly in terms of emotion regulation ability.
It is possible that mediators of the positive-psychology dimension - sleep relationship found previously may be indicative of healthy emotional regulation more generally i.e. the provision, promotion and bolstering of emotional regulation resources may provide a broader model within which previous single-mediation model findings can be situated.
Exploring an emotion regulation mechanism by which the positive psychology dimensions could be working to improve sleep will provide useful for new sleep-based interventions and makes up a second, exploratory aim of this study.

q4.value:
1) It is hypothesised that, collectively, the positive psychology dimensions (gratitude, optimism, mindfulness and self-compassion) will significantly contribute to sleep outcomes. 

2) It is hypothesised that emotion regulation will significantly mediate the relationships between each positive psychology dimension and sleep.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The current study will deploy an exploratory cross-sectional, questionnaire-based design to assess the relationships between trait levels of the four positive psychology dimensions (gratitude, optimism, mindfulness, self-compassion), emotional regulation and sleep outcomes.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be students recruited opportunistically via the University of Sussex's online SONA system. Participants will receive course credits (as part of their course requirement) in exchange for taking part in the study (online questionnaire). Participants must be at least 18 years old, and will be excluded from later analysis if they suffer from sleep-disorders, are shift-workers, or have missing data on variables required for the analysis question. 
Data collection will run until the end of term if needed. The aim is to collect 350 participants. If this number of participants cannot be obtained by SONA, recruitment will be supplemented by advertising the study opportunistically (e.g. via social media such as Facebook).

q13.value: We will attempt to recruit 350 participant responses to the questionnaire (assuming that not all will be included in final analysis due to incomplete responses or exclusion criteria i.e. sleep disorders or shift workers, we hope that this will allow for a sample of at least 300 complete responses).

q14.value: Collection will run until the end of the university term, or when the desired sample size (N = 350) is reached.

q15.value: Data collection will be stopped at the end of the university term, or when the desired sample size (N = 350) is reached.

question.value: N/A

The online questionnaire will involve the following assessment measures:
-	Gratitude: The Gratitude Questionnaire, GQ-6 (McCullough, 2013) 
-	Optimism: Life Orientation Test - Revised, LOT-R (Scheier et al., 1994)
-	Self-Compassion: Self-Compassion Scale - Short Form, SCS-SF (Raes et al, 2011)
-	Mindfulness: Five Factor Mindfulness Questionnaire - Short Form,  FFMQ-SF (Baer et al., 2008)
-	Affect: Positive Affect Negative Affect Scale, PANAS (Watson et al., 1988)
-	Emotion Regulation: Cognitive Emotion Regulation Questionnaire, CERQ (Garnefski et al., 2001)
-	Sleep: Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, PSQI (Buysse et al., 1989); SATED (Buysse, 2014); 
-	Bedtime Procrastination: Bedtime Procrastination Scale, BPS (Kroese, 2014)
-	Self-Regulation: Brief Self-Control Scale, BSCS (Tangey et al., 2004)
-       Stress: Perceived Stress Scale, PSS (Cohen et al., 1983)

For each of the measures of positive psychology, emotion regulation, affect (positive and negative), bedtime procrastination, perceived stress and self-regulation, a mean score will be calculated for each participant. For cases with missing data on one (or more) items within a scale, the within-participant mean will be calculated by averaging the participants’ response across the remaining items.
Global PSQI scores will be calculated according to the authors' instructions.
An affect balance score will also be calculated by subtracting the negative affect score from the positive affect score.

Hypothesis 1 - Collectively, the positive dimensions of psychology will be significantly associated with sleep outcomes. To test this, a multiple regression analysis will be used. The four positive psychology dimensions will be regressed onto sleep to determine whether there is a significant relationship and how much variance they account for when taken together.
 
Hypothesis 2 - Emotion regulation will significantly mediate the relationship between the dimensions of positive psychology and sleep outcomes. Mediation analysis will be conducted and a Sobel test will be used to assess whether the relationships between the positive dimensions and sleep are mediated by emotion regulation using four separate models, one for each dimension.

q21.value: The standard p < .05 criteria will be used for determining whether the statistical tests used in this study are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q23.value: For cases with missing data on one (or more) items within a scale, the within-participant mean will be calculated by averaging the participants’ response across the remaining items.

q24.value:
The opportunity will also be taken to look more closely at the differences between positive psychology dimensions in terms of their relative contribution to sleep outcomes as indicated by beta-weights in the multiple regression analysis used to assess Hypothesis 1. 

The opportunity will also be taken to explore the different emotion regulation strategies (as indicated by sub-scales of the CERQ measure) and how some strategies may be more or less related to certain positive psychology dimensions than others (e.g. acceptance and mindfulness; cognitive re-appraisal and optimism) – and to better sleep than others – however, as no previous research has investigated these relationships, this aspect of the study will be a purely exploratory opportunity and thus no specific hypotheses will be made.

The opportunity to measure and explore additional variables of interest (inc. bedtime procrastination, self-regulation, perceived stress and affect) will also be taken in the current study, however do not make up the main focus and no specific hypotheses are made.

registration_responses.q1: Relationships Between the Positive Psychology Dimensions, Emotion Regulation and Sleep
registration_responses.q2: Amber Tout, Eleanor Miles, Donna Jessop
registration_responses.q3:
Recent research has established links between the various dimensions of positive psychology (e.g. gratitude, optimism, mindfulness, self-compassion) and improved sleep quality and quantity (e.g. Emmons & McCullough, 2003; Lemola et al., 2011; 2013; Kemper et al., 2015; Wood et al., 2009; Black et al., 2015; Uchino et al., 2017; Howell et al., 2008; 2010; Hu et al., 2018; Butz et al., 2018). The  current study aims to replicate and extend these findings by assessing the relative importance of each dimension and its relationship to sleep, as opposed to focusing on one at a time. 
In addition, the current study will take the opportunity to explore the potential role of emotion regulation in this relationship. Previous attempts to explore the underlying mechanisms of this relationship have relied primary on single-mediator models, revealing the importance of variables such as depressive mood, rumination, perceived stress, positive and negative affect, pre-sleep cognitions, procrastination and cognitive reappraisal etc. in mediating the previously found relationships (e.g. Butz et al., 2018; Hu et al., 2018; Uchino et al. 2017; Wood et al., 2009). However, it remains unclear whether the positive-dimension - sleep relationship can be explained more broadly in terms of emotion regulation ability.
It is possible that mediators of the positive-psychology dimension - sleep relationship found previously may be indicative of healthy emotional regulation more generally i.e. the provision, promotion and bolstering of emotional regulation resources may provide a broader model within which previous single-mediation model findings can be situated.
Exploring an emotion regulation mechanism by which the positive psychology dimensions could be working to improve sleep will provide useful for new sleep-based interventions and makes up a second, exploratory aim of this study.
registration_responses.q4:
1) It is hypothesised that, collectively, the positive psychology dimensions (gratitude, optimism, mindfulness and self-compassion) will significantly contribute to sleep outcomes. 

2) It is hypothesised that emotion regulation will significantly mediate the relationships between each positive psychology dimension and sleep.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Classroom replication of: Self-control translates environmental attitudes into behavior (Berger, Wyss, Study 1, Mturk, 2019).

sample.value: The observations will be collected in the classroom. Thus, the total number of n is uncertain. However, the study is a classroom replication of other studies in this project, and all data will be collapsed for a pooled analysis in addition to analyzing the effects in this particular study.

analyses.value: We will run a panel probit regression to estimate our main hypothesis. The trials create a 25-times repeated measure with accept/forego bonus as the dependent variable in each trial. The independent variables of the model are participants NEP-R scores, their trait self-control scores, and the interaction thereof. In addition, we will run a pooled analysis controlling for the study for all studies we have conducted in this project.

outliers.value: We will exclude all participants who fail to correctly answer both of the two control questions. Additionally, we will exclude participants who fail to make at least 70% (18/25) of the decisions in the trials (decisions are timed and the trial automatically proceeds after 15 seconds).

dependent.value: The dependent variable consists of 25 decisions made by the participants. In each decision, the participant faces a trade-off between a financial reward (i.e., a bonus-opportunity on Mturk) that comes with actual CO2 emissions and foregoing the reward while avoiding the emission. The trials vary in bonus height and amount of CO2 emissions (5x5, fully crossed).

conditions.value: The main research question is correlational (effect of NEP-R moderated by self-control on choices), but the trials are a fully crossed 5x5 design enabling us to estimate the effect of CO2 emissions and bonus height on choices. Varying the level of CO2 emissions and bonus height enables us to create a measure of decision conlict (emissions per cent bonus) that will serve as an independent variable.

hypothesis.value: The main research question is whether trait self-control (measured by the BSCS, Tangney et al.) moderates the effect of environmental attitudes (measured by NEP-R) on pro-environmental choices. The main hypothesis is that high values of self-control increase the effect of NEP-R on sustainable decision-making.

summary.value: This is an update of the previous registration. It follows the fact that we realised that the textual corpus  we worked with is substantially incomplete. Therefore we decided to build a new dataset and a set of new tools for working with it (new lemmatization, new temporal metadata). The new dataset consists from 1458 deduplicated documents and 34,589,083 words. As in the case of the previous dataset, we will work only with a subselection of these, i.e. only with documents which are (1) at least to some extent datable (on the century basis), (2) which emerged before or at the year 400 CE, and (3) which might be classified as being either of "christian" or "pagan" provenience (i.e. not "jewish"). There is at least 867 of such documents, but perhaps even more than that. The uploaded scripts represent a snapshot of our workflow before we started to analyse these new data in respect to our research question.

attributes.title: Parents’ modeling and influence on teen’s self-efficacy and health behaviors moderated by parent-child relationship quality

q1.value: Parents’ modeling and influence on teen’s self-efficacy and health behaviors moderated by parent-child relationship quality

q2.value: Monique S. Nakamura, Chloe O. Huelsnitz, Alexander Rothman, Jeffry Simpson

q3.value:
Past literature explaining health behaviors have largely focused on intrapersonal factors that influence health behaviors compared to interpersonal factors. In order to clarify how relationships influence health behaviors, the proposed research will test different approaches parents take to influence their teen children’s health beliefs (e.g., self-efficacy) and health behaviors. We will further examine whether the quality of the parent-child relationship moderates the influence of parents’ behaviors on teens’ self-efficacy and health behaviors.
          Ma and Hample (2018) demonstrated that both teens’ perceived parental control and teens’ perceived parental modeling predicted teens’ self-efficacy, which in turn predicted teens’ consumption of fruits and vegetables. They focused on the teens’ perceptions of their parents’ behaviors. In the present study, we will focus on the parents’ reports of their own behaviors and their impact on their teens’ beliefs and behaviors. Furthermore, Ma and Hample did not test how relationship quality moderates these relations. Zhang, Davey, Larson, and Reicks (2019) demonstrated that parenting styles moderated the relation between parenting practices and teens’ health behaviors. However, Zhang et al. did not test the role of parenting styles, or the quality of the parent-child relationship, on parental modeling and health beliefs. 
          To address these gaps in the literature, the present study will examine the influence of parental modeling and parental social influence on teens’ health beliefs and health behaviors across four behavioral domains: (1) fruit and vegetable consumption, (2) junk food and sugary drink consumption, (3) physical activity, and (4) sedentary behavior. We operationalized modeling as parents’ reports of their health behaviors and social influence as parents’ reports of their use of direct control. We will further investigate the moderating role of parent-child relationship quality on parents’ behaviors and teens’ health beliefs and behaviors.

q4.value:
Primary
1.	To what extent are parents’ modeling and social influence uniquely or jointly associated with teens’ health behaviors across the four behavioral domains (fruit and vegetable consumption, junk food and sugary drink consumption, physical activity, and sedentary behavior)?
a.	H1A: High levels of parents’ health behaviors (modeling) will be associated with high levels of teens’ health behaviors
b.	H1B: High levels of parents’ social influence will be associated with lower levels of teens’ health behaviors 
c.	RQ1C: To what extent does the degree of association (magnitude) in parents’ modeling and/or social influence vary across the four domains?
2.	How does the quality of the parent-child relationship moderate the relation between parents’ modeling and/or social influence and teens’ health behaviors?
a.	H2A: High levels of parents’ health behaviors will be associated with high levels of teens’ health behaviors (i.e., modeling), especially for teens with parents high in warmth and demandingness 
b.	RQ2B: To what extent does the moderating effect of relationship quality vary across the four domains?
3.	To what extent are parents’ modeling and social influence uniquely or jointly associated with teens’ self-efficacy across the four health domains (fruit and vegetable consumption, junk food and sugary drink consumption, physical activity, and sedentary behavior)?
a.	H3A: High levels of parents’ health behaviors (modeling) will be associated with high levels of teens’ self-efficacy
b.	H3B: High levels of parents’ social influence will be associated with lower teens’ self-efficacy 
c.	RQ3C: To what extent do the parents’ modeling and/or social influence vary across the four domains?
4.	How does the quality of the parent-child relationship moderate the relation between parents’ modeling and/or social influence and teens’ self-efficacy?
a.	H4A: High levels of parents’ social influence will be associated with low levels of teens’ self-efficacy for teens with parents low in warmth and demandingness
b.	RQ4B: To what extent does the parents’ modeling and/or social influence vary across the four domains?
5.	To what extent are teens’ self-efficacy uniquely or jointly associated with teens’ health behaviors across the four health domains (fruit and vegetable consumption, junk food and sugary drink consumption, physical activity, and sedentary behavior)?
a.	H5A: High levels of teens’ self-efficacy will be associated with high levels of teens’ health behaviors 
b.	RQ5B: To what extent do the parents’ modeling and/or social influence vary across the four domains?
6.	How does the quality of the parent-child relationship moderate the relation between teens’ self-efficacy and teens’ health behaviors?
a.	H6A: High levels of teens’ self-efficacy will predict high levels of teens’ health behaviors, especially for teens with parents high in warmth and demandingness (exploratory) 
b.	RQ6B: To what extent does the parents’ modeling and/or social influence vary across the four domains?
Secondary/exploratory
1.	Does teens’ self-efficacy contribute to the association between parents’ modeling and/or social influence and teens’ health behaviors? 
a.	Teens’ self-efficacy will contribute to the association between parent’s health behaviors and teen’s health behaviors (exploratory)
b.	Teens’ self-efficacy will contribute to the association between parents’ social influence and teen’s health behaviors (exploratory)

attributes.title: Scoring the Revised Markers of Adulthood Scale
attributes.description: This component is a collection of the materials utilized for a comparison of three common methods for scoring the MoA conducted on a compilation of both new and revised items.
tags: Inventory of the Dimensions of Emerging Adulthood

q1.value: Comparing Scoring Methods on a Reconstructed Markers of Adulthood Scale

q2.value: Kaley Norman, Leydin Hernandez, Angela DeDios, Randy Martinez, Joseph McFall, Holly M. Chalk, William J. Chopik, Jon Grahe

q3.value:
Arnett (1998) proposed the Markers of Adulthood (MoA) to capture the developmental tasks that are important for emerging adults when discerning whether an individual has reached adulthood. These items have since been used to explore how individuals are transitioning into adulthood by determining what milestones are important to them compared to those they achieve. However, recent studies of adulthood have illuminated changes in the transitional markers associated with reaching adult status; namely, there is a growing focus on subjective milestones as opposed to objective external markers. Essentially, new adults are no longer interested in defining their status based on marriage, child rearing, or living independently, but instead discern their own adult status based on relative maturity markers such as developing greater consideration for others and recognizing their own capabilities and shortcomings. Thus, Norman et al. (2020) developed an updated collection of transitional markers, including several from Arnett’s original configuration as well as some new items, to better reflect the current trends in adulthood development.

The current study utilizes the Revised MoA scale to examine three scoring methods used in prior research: raw scores, dichotomous choices, and fit scoring. We will compare  these methods separately for the original and new MoA items to identify whether one provides stronger predictive  validity for measuring adulthood status. Data collection began with 1161 and resulted in 861 participants across seven national institutions. Of the participants, 288 identified as males, 565 as females, and 7 as nonbinary, gender nonconforming, or other. Participants ranged in age from 18- 62 with an average age of 21. Data collection ensued via an online survey including the Inventory of the Dimensions of Emerging Adulthood (IDEA;Arnett, 2000), 22 original MoA items (Arnett, 2001) with some phrasing revisions, 14 new MoA items (Norman et al., 2020), the Perceived-Esteem Inventory (Hermann, Lucas, & Friedrich, 2008), and the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (Rosenberg, 1965). 

We will complete the following scoring procedures on the Markers of Adulthood items, computing two sets of scales- one for old items and one for new. For Raw and Dichotomous scoring, we will follow the methods of deDios (2015); for Fit scoring, we will emulate Sharon (2016). Finally, we will regress the six IDEA subscales, Self-Esteem and Perceived Esteem, age and age-squared onto the three sets of MoA scores for New and Original MoA Scales. We expect Raw Scoring to be the strongest predictor of adulthood status, although it will highlight extreme scores and exhibit more variability. We also hypothesize Fit Scoring will be a stronger predictor of adulthood status than Dichotomous, and will have the strongest correlation with age and IDEA scores. Lastly, we expect the new MoA items to be better predictors of adulthood status than the original items.

q4.value:
Raw vs Dichotomous - Raw will have more variability, will maximize the combination of importance and achievement, but will also highlight extreme scores. Raw will be the strongest predictor. 

Dichotomous vs Fit - Fit will be more closely aligned to the respondents’ preferences, and will be a stronger predictor. Dichotomous will not be a strong predictor.

Raw vs Fit - Fit will have a higher correlation to age than raw. Both will have low correlations with the IDEA, although Fit will be higher.

New Vs. Old -- We do not expect New to outperform Old items within our sample since these items were added to be more inclusive of populations beyond the typical college sample. Therefore, our comparisons of New versus Old MoA scoring across the Raw, Dichotomous, and Fit will primarily be to determine if the New items are equivalent to the Old items across the various effects.

Participants were recruited by contributors from seven universities across the United States. Some were collected from participant pools at various institutions, while others were collected from  social media platforms (e.g. instagram, facebook, and snapchat), or via word of mouth. Participants had to be at least 18 years old to complete the online survey and received no payment for their participation. Some received course credit or completed the task as part of a research requirement for a psychology course, but this was not tracked on the individual data. All individuals over 18 were invited to participate with no exclusion criteria other than age, to capture a wider demographic of individuals. We ensured eligibility by requiring participants to agree they were above the age of 18 at the beginning of the survey and including an age verification question at the end of the survey.

Participant responses will be removed from the dataset if they fail the attention check placed within the survey, if more than 20% of the items are left blank, or if all the items on more than one full page are left unanswered. Data collection will end January 22nd.

question.value:
Adulthood Status Attainment- Measured using the Revised Markers of Adulthood Scale (Norman & Grahe, 2019). Defined by an individual’s beliefs concerning the experiences most relevant to being considered an adult and the level at which participants have achieved them. Items were adapted from the original Markers of Adulthood Scale (Arnett, 2001), class discussions, and formulation by authors. Sample items include: “Employed full-time,” “married,” “take responsibility for actions,” “capable of supporting a family financially”.

Inventory of the Dimensions of Emerging Adulthood (IDEA; Reifman, Arnett, & Colwell, 2007)- Measures the extent to which an individual is experiencing characteristics of emerging adulthood. Scores are calculated overall and as six dimensions: Identity Exploration, Negativity/Instability, Experimentation/Possibilities, Feeling In-Between, Self-Focused, and Other-Focused. 
 
Self-Esteem- Measured using the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (Rosenberg, 1965). A measure of a participants positive and negative feelings about themselves. Participants are asked to provide their level agreement to items such as “I feel I have a number of good qualities” and “I have very little to be proud of.”
 
Perceived-Esteem-Measured using the Perceived-Esteem Inventory (Hermann, Lucas, and Friedrich 2008). Perceived-esteem is an individual’s belief concerning how others feel about them. The PEI provides a list of general people a participant has in their life, including family (i.e., mother, father, and siblings), work relationships (i.e., boss, coworker), peers (roommate, significant others, best friend), and other social contacts (coach, neighbor, friend’s parents), and asks how positively they belief that person regards them.

Age- Some variables will be compared to the age of the participants

To examine the relationships between adulthood attainment and predictor variables we will employ the following regression equation

YOldMoA_RawScore = b_age + b_age^2 + b_IDEA + b_self-esteem
YOldMoA_DicScore = b_age + b_age^2 + b_IDEA + b_self-esteem
YOldMoA_FitScore = b_age + b_age^2 + b_IDEA + b_self-esteem
YNewMoA_RawScore = b_age + b_age^2 + b_IDEA + b_self-esteem
YNewMoA_DicScore = b_age + b_age^2 + b_IDEA + b_self-esteem
YNewMoA_FitScore = b_age + b_age^2 + b_IDEA + b_self-esteem

We will not include the scores from multiple methods of scoring the MoA as separate predictors in the same regression model because this would lead to high multicollinearity. 

We will then compare different regression models by using a relative weights analysis of unique and shared variance between the MoA scores and the adulthood status variables to assess the contributions of each predictor; adjusted R² values will be included in the regression outcomes.

registration_responses.q1: Comparing Scoring Methods on a Reconstructed Markers of Adulthood Scale
registration_responses.q2: Kaley Norman, Leydin Hernandez, Angela DeDios, Randy Martinez, Joseph McFall, Holly M. Chalk, William J. Chopik, Jon Grahe
registration_responses.q3:
Arnett (1998) proposed the Markers of Adulthood (MoA) to capture the developmental tasks that are important for emerging adults when discerning whether an individual has reached adulthood. These items have since been used to explore how individuals are transitioning into adulthood by determining what milestones are important to them compared to those they achieve. However, recent studies of adulthood have illuminated changes in the transitional markers associated with reaching adult status; namely, there is a growing focus on subjective milestones as opposed to objective external markers. Essentially, new adults are no longer interested in defining their status based on marriage, child rearing, or living independently, but instead discern their own adult status based on relative maturity markers such as developing greater consideration for others and recognizing their own capabilities and shortcomings. Thus, Norman et al. (2020) developed an updated collection of transitional markers, including several from Arnett’s original configuration as well as some new items, to better reflect the current trends in adulthood development.

The current study utilizes the Revised MoA scale to examine three scoring methods used in prior research: raw scores, dichotomous choices, and fit scoring. We will compare  these methods separately for the original and new MoA items to identify whether one provides stronger predictive  validity for measuring adulthood status. Data collection began with 1161 and resulted in 861 participants across seven national institutions. Of the participants, 288 identified as males, 565 as females, and 7 as nonbinary, gender nonconforming, or other. Participants ranged in age from 18- 62 with an average age of 21. Data collection ensued via an online survey including the Inventory of the Dimensions of Emerging Adulthood (IDEA;Arnett, 2000), 22 original MoA items (Arnett, 2001) with some phrasing revisions, 14 new MoA items (Norman et al., 2020), the Perceived-Esteem Inventory (Hermann, Lucas, & Friedrich, 2008), and the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (Rosenberg, 1965). 

We will complete the following scoring procedures on the Markers of Adulthood items, computing two sets of scales- one for old items and one for new. For Raw and Dichotomous scoring, we will follow the methods of deDios (2015); for Fit scoring, we will emulate Sharon (2016). Finally, we will regress the six IDEA subscales, Self-Esteem and Perceived Esteem, age and age-squared onto the three sets of MoA scores for New and Original MoA Scales. We expect Raw Scoring to be the strongest predictor of adulthood status, although it will highlight extreme scores and exhibit more variability. We also hypothesize Fit Scoring will be a stronger predictor of adulthood status than Dichotomous, and will have the strongest correlation with age and IDEA scores. Lastly, we expect the new MoA items to be better predictors of adulthood status than the original items.

Raw vs Fit - Fit will have a higher correlation to age than raw. Both will have low correlations with the IDEA, although Fit will be higher.

New Vs. Old -- We do not expect New to outperform Old items within our sample since these items were added to be more inclusive of populations beyond the typical college sample. Therefore, our comparisons of New versus Old MoA scoring across the Raw, Dichotomous, and Fit will primarily be to determine if the New items are equivalent to the Old items across the various effects.

attributes.title: An Experimental Design to Investigate the Impact of Differential Reinforcement on Deviant Behaviour under the Influence of Deviant Peer Behaviour

q1.value: An Experimental Design to Investigate the Impact of Differential Reinforcement on Deviant Behaviour under the Influence of Deviant Peer Behaviour

q3.value: Relying on Social Learning Theory, the exposure to deviant peer behaviour is expected to be associated with an increased probability of displaying deviant behaviour. Furthermore, a sanctioning compared to a rewarding outcome of deviancy in a former situation is expected to influence deviant behaviour, when individuals get exposed to a deviant peer in a similar subsequent situation. As the impact of differential reinforcement has never been tested experimentally in the frame of social learning theory, this study design aims to find empirical support for the mentioned causal mechanism.

q4.value:
H1: Being exposed to deviant peer behaviour leads to an increased probability to behave deviant as well, compared to no exposure to deviancy. 
H2: Having been exposed to a similar situation before, where deviant behaviour has been rewarded, increases the probability that an individual behaves deviant when he or she is exposed to deviant peer behaviour in a subsequent situation.
H3: Having been exposed to a similar situation before, where deviant behaviour has been sanctioned, decreases the probability that an individual behaves deviant when he or she is exposed to deviant peer behaviour in a subsequent situation.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Between subjects design with 2 factors: 1. outcome of deviancy in first appointment positive, negative or not given and 2. exposure to deviant peer in second appointment given or not given

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Recruitment of participants is planned to be conducted among students of the University of Cologne. University students aged 18 and older can participate. Mailing lists of students that signed up for participating in experiments, flyers and advertisement at the University of Cologne, shall call attention to the experiment. In the advertisement, the experiment shall attract students with the possibility to gain 20 € and a gift card of local businesses worth 15 €. The advertisement includes a link to a homepage, where participants can register online for suggested dates for both appointments of the study.

q13.value: The target sample size is 232 participants. An overrecruitment of 10 % (255 participants) will be aspired, assuming that not all will appear to both appointments.

q14.value: The software program G*Power was used to conduct a power analysis. The goal was to obtain 0.95 power to detect a medium effect size of 0.3 at the standard 0.05 alpha error probability.

question.value: In the first appointment, cheating behaviour becomes rewarded (treatment group 1), sanctioned (treatment group 2) or is not possible (control groups 1 and 2). In the second appointment, participants get exposed to a deviant peer (treatment group 1 and 2, control group 2) or do not get exposed to a deviant peer (control group 1).

Wheter participants do cheat or do not cheat in the first appointment shall be measured by the number of people that click on a link which provides solution words of the given task.
The outcome variable of the experiment is the amount of stolen gift cards in the second appointment.

A chi-square test shall be conducted to test the significance in the different outcome proportions per group. Additionaly, linear probability models which include control variables shall be conducted to account for potential selection effects, as the assignment to a group bases on time slot availability.

attributes.title: The effects of visuo-spatial perspective-taking and others’ reciprocity on trusting behavior

q1.value: The effects of visuo-spatial perspective-taking and others’ reciprocity on trusting behavior

q3.value:
Previous research suggests that perspective-taking leads to higher levels of cooperation and trust. Some of this research has shown that this effect might depend on the nature of the social interaction (e.g. cooperative vs competitive). The rationale underlying these findings is that perspective-taking enables us to more accurately intuit another person’s thoughts, which, in turn, can facilitate judgments of  that person’s future behavior and therefore inform decisions (not) to trust that person. However, this rationale has not been experimentally tested directly so far.

The present study will manipulate perspective-taking and the trustworthiness of other players within a trust game. Trustworthiness of the other players will be established via their behavior during the trust game (i.e., how often they reciprocate and return money to the participant). Before every trial of the trust game, perspective-taking will be manipulated by either having participants take the visual perspective of the other players or their own egocentric perspective. Participants' trust in the other players will be measured over several games by inspecting their willingness to entrust the other players with money during the trust game.

It is predicted that participants generally learn over time which of the other players are trustworthy or not. It is furthermore predicted that this learning will be accelerated by perspective-taking, which allows participants to more accurately intuit the other players' thoughts, thereby allowing them to more quickly forming an impression of those players as trustworthy or not. Therefore, compared to other players whose perspective participants do not take, participants will more quickly increase/decrease the rate with which they transfer money to other trustworthy/untrustworthy players whose perspective they repeatedly took.

q4.value:
1) Participants show higher levels of behavioral trust towards trustworthy compared to non-trustworthy players within repeated trust games. This effect will be tested as a main effect of Trustworthiness and a two-way interaction between Trustworthiness and Game Round.

2) For untrustworthy other players, participants willl more quickly (i.e., after fewer rounds of the trustgame) show lower levels of trust if they took that other player's perspective (compared to the untrustworthy other player whose perspective they ignored). For trustworthy other players, conversely, participants will more quickly show higher levels of trust if they took that other player's perspective (compared to the trustworthy other player whose perspective they ignored). This effect will be tested as a three-way interaction between Perspective, Trustworthiness, and Game Round.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The study has a 2 (Perspective: egocentric vs. perspective-taking) × 2 (Trustworthiness: high vs. low) x 8 game rounds (1 vs. 2 vs. 3 vs. 4 vs. 5 vs. 6 vs. 7 vs. 8) experimental within-subjects design. 

There will be 8 blocks, in which participants will complete two consecutive tasks (perspective-taking task and trust game) with four different other players.  For two of those players (one trustworthy and one untrustworthy player), participants will always remain egocentric during the perspective-taking task while for the other two players, participants will always take the other's perspective.

q9.value: The order in which participants will encounter the four players for each block will be randomized anew for each block. Furthermore, pseudonyms for the other players will be generated anew for every participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Data will be collected on Prolific Academic. Participants will be paid a small monetary compensation for participating in a study that will take around 10 minutes. Participants must be at least 18 years old.

q13.value: Our target sample size is N = 205 valid cases.

q14.value: To conduct a power analysis, we used the software program G*Power. The power analysis was based conservatively on the assumption of a small effect size (η2p = .01) for the hypothesized three-way interaction between Perspective, Trustworthiness, and Game Round. The target sample size is needed to detect this effect with a power of (1-β)=.80.

q15.value: Data collection will be stopped once the target sample size is reached.

question.value:
Perspective-taking:
Participants will complete 32 trials of a visuo-spatial perspective-taking task that has been used in previous research on perspective-taking. Participants will be instructed to either remain their egocentric perspective or to take the perspective of an avatar sitting on a table of an angular disparity of 160° (rotated clockwise or counterclockwise).  Their task will be to virtually “grab” one of the two objects in front of the avatar (a pistol and a ﬂower; adapted from a previous study) by pressing the A or L key (corresponding to the left and right hand) from either their own or the other player’s perspective. 

Trustworthiness:
Participants will play 32 rounds of the trust game, always immediately after they completed the perspective-taking task. In this game, both players will be endowed with 10 tokens., which the participant in turn can 'KEEP' or 'SEND'. If she decides to 'KEEP' the token, both players will end up with 10 tokens. If she decides to 'SEND' the tokens, the amount of tokens will be tripled and it depends on the other player's decision whether to split the tokens (20 token s for each player) or to keep it all for her own (40 for the other player, nothing for the participant).  They will play eight games each with four distinct players, which will be identifiable via a randomly generated pseudonym. Among the four players, two players will show cooperative behavior by always sending back 20 tokens, if the participant decided to 'SEND'  (high trustworthiness condition). The two remaining players will demonstrate unfair behavior by never sending back tokens to the participant (low trustworthiness condition). 

Game rounds.:
All participants will play eight blocks in which they will encounter each of the four players once. This number of blocks is chosen to ensure that the participants will have the opportunity to learn about the respective player’s behavior.

The main dependent variable is participants behavioral trust during the trust game. The level of behavioral trust in the trust game will be determined by the frequency with which participants decide to trust the other players by sending them money.

Further measures that are taken during the study are:
- Self-reported trust towards the other players (10-point likert scale)
- Self-reported liking of the other players (10-point likert scale)
- Reaction times on the perspective-taking task (in ms)
- Errors on the perspective-taking task (in %)
- Demographic data (age and gender)
All data will be analyzed on the trial level and therefore no indices are computed.

Main analysis:
All hypotheses will be tested in a binomial mixed model analysis that will include fixed effects of perspective-taking (contrast coded as -0.5 for egocentric trails vs. +0.5 for visuo-spatial perspective-taking), trustworthiness (coded as -0.5 for low trustworthiness vs. +0.5 for high trustworthiness), and game round (mean centered), as well as a random slope for the participant. The dependent variable for this analysis is the behavioral trust during the trust game. In case the mixed model does not converge, the random effects structure will be reduced until it does, in line with common recommendations.

Hypothesis 1 - participants trust cooperative players more than uncooperative players - will be tested by inspecting the main effect of trustworthiness. Hypothesis 2 will be tested by inspecting the three-way interaction between all fixed effects.

Although not part of the main confirmatory analyses of this study, the two-way interaction between Trustworthiness and Game Rounds can be seen as a test of the general learning effect: Do participants adapt their behavior depending on the trustworthiness of the other player?

Additional analyses:
- Perspective-taking reaction times and errors will be subjected to a similar linear mixed model with these variables serving as dependent variables instead of behavioral trust. These analyses are performed to ensure that participants perform the perspective-taking task as intended. It is predicted that perspective-taking, compared to egocentric trials, will lead to higher reaction times and error rates.
- Self-reported liking and trust for the other players will be analyzed with a 2 (Perspective: Egocentric vs. Perspective-taking) x 2 (Trustworthiness: High vs. low) repeated-measures ANOVA. It is predicted that these results parallel the results of the main analysis, that is, at the end of the experiment participants will report higher liking and trustworthiness for trustworthy players than for untrustworthy players. These differences should furthermore be larger for the players whose perspective participants took.

registration_responses.q1: The effects of visuo-spatial perspective-taking and others’ reciprocity on trusting behavior
registration_responses.q3:
Previous research suggests that perspective-taking leads to higher levels of cooperation and trust. Some of this research has shown that this effect might depend on the nature of the social interaction (e.g. cooperative vs competitive). The rationale underlying these findings is that perspective-taking enables us to more accurately intuit another person’s thoughts, which, in turn, can facilitate judgments of  that person’s future behavior and therefore inform decisions (not) to trust that person. However, this rationale has not been experimentally tested directly so far.

The present study will manipulate perspective-taking and the trustworthiness of other players within a trust game. Trustworthiness of the other players will be established via their behavior during the trust game (i.e., how often they reciprocate and return money to the participant). Before every trial of the trust game, perspective-taking will be manipulated by either having participants take the visual perspective of the other players or their own egocentric perspective. Participants' trust in the other players will be measured over several games by inspecting their willingness to entrust the other players with money during the trust game.

It is predicted that participants generally learn over time which of the other players are trustworthy or not. It is furthermore predicted that this learning will be accelerated by perspective-taking, which allows participants to more accurately intuit the other players' thoughts, thereby allowing them to more quickly forming an impression of those players as trustworthy or not. Therefore, compared to other players whose perspective participants do not take, participants will more quickly increase/decrease the rate with which they transfer money to other trustworthy/untrustworthy players whose perspective they repeatedly took.
registration_responses.q4:
1) Participants show higher levels of behavioral trust towards trustworthy compared to non-trustworthy players within repeated trust games. This effect will be tested as a main effect of Trustworthiness and a two-way interaction between Trustworthiness and Game Round.

2) For untrustworthy other players, participants willl more quickly (i.e., after fewer rounds of the trustgame) show lower levels of trust if they took that other player's perspective (compared to the untrustworthy other player whose perspective they ignored). For trustworthy other players, conversely, participants will more quickly show higher levels of trust if they took that other player's perspective (compared to the trustworthy other player whose perspective they ignored). This effect will be tested as a three-way interaction between Perspective, Trustworthiness, and Game Round.

The power analysis was based conservatively on the assumption of a small effect size (η2p = .01) for the hypothesized three-way interaction between Perspective, Trustworthiness, and Game Round. The target sample size is needed to detect this effect with a power of (1-β)=.80.

registration_responses.q8.question:
The study has a 2 (Perspective: egocentric vs. perspective-taking) × 2 (Trustworthiness: high vs. low) x 8 game rounds (1 vs. 2 vs. 3 vs. 4 vs. 5 vs. 6 vs. 7 vs. 8) experimental within-subjects design. 

There will be 8 blocks, in which participants will complete two consecutive tasks (perspective-taking task and trust game) with four different other players.  For two of those players (one trustworthy and one untrustworthy player), participants will always remain egocentric during the perspective-taking task while for the other two players, participants will always take the other's perspective.
registration_responses.q12.question: Data will be collected on Prolific Academic. Participants will be paid a small monetary compensation for participating in a study that will take around 10 minutes. Participants must be at least 18 years old.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Perspective-taking:
Participants will complete 32 trials of a visuo-spatial perspective-taking task that has been used in previous research on perspective-taking. Participants will be instructed to either remain their egocentric perspective or to take the perspective of an avatar sitting on a table of an angular disparity of 160° (rotated clockwise or counterclockwise).  Their task will be to virtually “grab” one of the two objects in front of the avatar (a pistol and a ﬂower; adapted from a previous study) by pressing the A or L key (corresponding to the left and right hand) from either their own or the other player’s perspective. 

Trustworthiness:
Participants will play 32 rounds of the trust game, always immediately after they completed the perspective-taking task. In this game, both players will be endowed with 10 tokens., which the participant in turn can 'KEEP' or 'SEND'. If she decides to 'KEEP' the token, both players will end up with 10 tokens. If she decides to 'SEND' the tokens, the amount of tokens will be tripled and it depends on the other player's decision whether to split the tokens (20 token s for each player) or to keep it all for her own (40 for the other player, nothing for the participant).  They will play eight games each with four distinct players, which will be identifiable via a randomly generated pseudonym. Among the four players, two players will show cooperative behavior by always sending back 20 tokens, if the participant decided to 'SEND'  (high trustworthiness condition). The two remaining players will demonstrate unfair behavior by never sending back tokens to the participant (low trustworthiness condition). 

Game rounds.:
All participants will play eight blocks in which they will encounter each of the four players once. This number of blocks is chosen to ensure that the participants will have the opportunity to learn about the respective player’s behavior.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The main dependent variable is participants behavioral trust during the trust game. The level of behavioral trust in the trust game will be determined by the frequency with which participants decide to trust the other players by sending them money.

Further measures that are taken during the study are:
- Self-reported trust towards the other players (10-point likert scale)
- Self-reported liking of the other players (10-point likert scale)
- Reaction times on the perspective-taking task (in ms)
- Errors on the perspective-taking task (in %)
- Demographic data (age and gender)
registration_responses.q18.question: All data will be analyzed on the trial level and therefore no indices are computed.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Main analysis:
All hypotheses will be tested in a binomial mixed model analysis that will include fixed effects of perspective-taking (contrast coded as -0.5 for egocentric trails vs. +0.5 for visuo-spatial perspective-taking), trustworthiness (coded as -0.5 for low trustworthiness vs. +0.5 for high trustworthiness), and game round (mean centered), as well as a random slope for the participant. The dependent variable for this analysis is the behavioral trust during the trust game. In case the mixed model does not converge, the random effects structure will be reduced until it does, in line with common recommendations.

Hypothesis 1 - participants trust cooperative players more than uncooperative players - will be tested by inspecting the main effect of trustworthiness. Hypothesis 2 will be tested by inspecting the three-way interaction between all fixed effects.

Although not part of the main confirmatory analyses of this study, the two-way interaction between Trustworthiness and Game Rounds can be seen as a test of the general learning effect: Do participants adapt their behavior depending on the trustworthiness of the other player?

Additional analyses:
- Perspective-taking reaction times and errors will be subjected to a similar linear mixed model with these variables serving as dependent variables instead of behavioral trust. These analyses are performed to ensure that participants perform the perspective-taking task as intended. It is predicted that perspective-taking, compared to egocentric trials, will lead to higher reaction times and error rates.
- Self-reported liking and trust for the other players will be analyzed with a 2 (Perspective: Egocentric vs. Perspective-taking) x 2 (Trustworthiness: High vs. low) repeated-measures ANOVA. It is predicted that these results parallel the results of the main analysis, that is, at the end of the experiment participants will report higher liking and trustworthiness for trustworthy players than for untrustworthy players. These differences should furthermore be larger for the players whose perspective participants took.
